propositions.text: Narrator sees Wang Quansheng's death photo and is disturbed.
Narrator fears his involvement in hiding Wang Quansheng's body.
Narrator returns to his room at the police station.
Narrator feels tired and prone to nightmares since returning from Guangchuan King's tomb.
Narrator recalls the photo of Wang Quansheng and questions his uncorroded body and reappearance.
Professor's body in Guangchuan King's tomb was already inexplicable.
Wang Quansheng's reappearance is a major blow.
Narrator wonders if contact with the Dragon Coffin leads to a curse and corpse transformation.
Narrator wakes up from a nightmare.
He sees a figure in the corner of his room.
Narrator approaches the figure, realizing it's Wang Quansheng.
Wang Quansheng has a twisted neck and long fingernails.
Narrator struggles and recalls the Yellow River Dragon Eye incident.
He feels if he hadn't met Wang Quansheng at Nangong or gone to Yellow River Eye, things would be different.
Narrator desperately tries to escape and open the locked door.
Wang Quansheng grabs narrator's neck.
Narrator screams and wakes up from the nightmare.
He attributes the dream to his anxieties about Wang Quansheng's death.
Narrator sees the figure in the corner again.
The figure turns out to be Shao Ye.
Shao Ye explains he slept in the room with the narrator.
Shao Ye explains he was trying to catch mice.
Narrator recounts his nightmare to Shao Ye.
Shao Ye jokes about Wang Quansheng bringing back bronze artifacts.
Narrator reflects on his own actions regarding Wang Quansheng's body.
Yatou arrives to invite them to breakfast.
Huang Zhihua is more accommodating after yesterday's events.
They are allowed to leave with prior notice.
At breakfast, Yatou reveals the treasures from Guangchuan King's tomb are with the police.
The inscription on Guangchuan King's epitaph is lost.
Huang Zhihua rushes in with a grim expression.
Huang Zhihua asks if anyone left their rooms last night.
Huang Zhihua reveals Wang Quansheng's body is missing from the morgue.
This news causes the narrator to tremble.
Shao Ye is shocked.
Yatou is frightened and leans on the narrator.
Huang Zhihua explains Wang Quansheng's body was taken to the morgue after being brought back, awaiting family contact.
The narrator questions who would steal a body, especially Wang Quansheng's.
The narrator considers the possibility of the body walking out on its own.
He relates it to the professor's and Lao Bian's bodies appearing in Guangchuan King's tomb.
The phone rings, startling the narrator.
Huang Zhihua receives a call and learns of a death at Shao Ye's guesthouse, where Wang Quansheng's body also appeared.
The narrator realizes Wang Quansheng might have gone to the guesthouse to find him.
Huang Zhihua suggests they all go to the guesthouse as they are all connected to the case.
They arrive at the guesthouse to find a commotion and police presence.
The narrator recognizes the room as his usual lodging.
Inside the room, they find a new corpse and Wang Quansheng's body.
The new victim is a man around thirty, found in a bizarre pose with bruising on his neck, suggesting strangulation.
The narrator realizes the death pose resembles that of Dan Jun.
Wang Quansheng's body is also present, seemingly staring at the narrator.
Huang Zhihua examines the bodies and notes Wang Quansheng's corpse does not appear fresh.
Huang Zhihua finds no signs of forced entry.
They return to the police station, and Huang Zhihua questions them.
The narrator feels consumed by anxiety.
Huang Zhihua, along with an old man and two others (Nan Pazi), questions them about Wang Quansheng's past visit to Taiyuan.
The old man states Wang Quansheng has been dead for at least six months.
The old man cryptically tells the narrator, 'The middle corpse is alive...'
The narrator falls off his chair in shock.
The old man implies the narrator's actions led to his misfortune.
Huang Zhihua asks the narrator to explain how Wang Quansheng died and what 'middle corpse' means.
The narrator confesses to buying bronze artifacts from Wang Quansheng and using Shao Ye's tricycle to dispose of his body six months prior.
Huang Zhihua, the old man, and Yatou and Shao Ye react to the narrator's confession.
Huang Zhihua offers the narrator a deal: assist in the investigation to avoid prison.
The narrator is suspicious but agrees, as do Yatou and Shao Ye.
The narrator contemplates the curse and the possibility of 'corpse transformation' (尸变).
He wonders about the implications of the 'lower corpse' (下尸) and 'middle corpse' (中尸) phenomena.
The old man advises to cremate the newly deceased and mentions difficulty in cremating Wang Quansheng's body.
The narrator is relieved to have confessed but still worried.
In the evening, Shao Ye arranges for drinks and snacks.
Yatou seems preoccupied.
The old man (Nan Pazi) arrives at their room.
The narrator feels uneasy around the old man.
The old man joins them and eats and drinks their food.
The old man claims the narrator should thank him.
The narrator suspects the old man is responsible for revealing the 'middle corpse' information.
The old man seems to read the narrator's thoughts.
The old man says he has a matter to discuss, related to the Yellow River Dragon Coffin.
The old man mentions needing the narrator to go to 'Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye' (影昆仑的风眼).
The old man explains that to break the Dragon Coffin's curse, they need 'Golden Building Maidens' (金楼素女), which he believes are buried in Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye.
The narrator dismisses the idea as superstition and irrelevant to him.
The old man challenges him to scientifically explain the curse if he dismisses it.
The old man states he has arranged with Huang Zhihua to investigate Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye after dealing with Wang Quansheng's body.
The old man proposes two options: go to Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye or spend his life in prison.
The narrator expresses anger at the unfair proposal.
The old man hints at potential gains from Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye.
Yatou volunteers to accompany the narrator to Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye.
The old man gives Yatou a beautiful embroidered pouch as a gift.
The old man then gives Yatou a white jade bracelet with a red spot, calling it a 'lover's jade bracelet' (相思玉镯).
Hu Lai bursts in, reporting trouble with 'the God of Wealth' (财神), who is implied to be Wang Quansheng.
The old man is agitated by the news.
Hu Lai explains that 'the God of Wealth' (Wang Quansheng's reanimated corpse) refused to be moved and almost injured Uncle Luo.
The old man reveals that Wang Quansheng's body retained a soul, which could turn into a more dangerous ghost if cremated improperly.

concepts.name: Wang Quansheng
concepts.context: A dead character whose reappearance and corpse transformation are central to the plot.

concepts.name: Narrator (Xu Sanqing)
concepts.context: The protagonist, involved in hiding Wang Quansheng's body and experiencing supernatural events.

concepts.name: Shao Ye
concepts.context: The narrator's friend, owner of the guesthouse, and companion in the investigation.

concepts.name: Yatou
concepts.context: A female companion who joins the narrator and Shao Ye in their adventures.

concepts.name: Huang Zhihua
concepts.context: A military figure assigned to investigate the case, working with the protagonists.

concepts.name: Dragon Coffin (Long Guan)
concepts.context: A mysterious artifact linked to a curse and supernatural phenomena.

concepts.name: Guangchuan King's tomb
concepts.context: A location where the narrator and his companions found treasures and experienced supernatural events.

concepts.name: Old man (Nan Pazi)
concepts.context: An elderly, mysterious figure with knowledge of ancient burial practices and supernatural phenomena.

concepts.name: Corpse transformation (Shi Bian)
concepts.context: The supernatural phenomenon of a dead body becoming animated.

concepts.name: Middle corpse (Zhong Shi)
concepts.context: A supernatural state of a corpse, implied to be a level of animation or reanimation.

concepts.name: Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye
concepts.context: A mysterious and dangerous location mentioned as a key to breaking the curse.

concepts.name: Golden Building Maidens (Jin Lou Su Nü)
concepts.context: An artifact or entity believed to be buried in Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye, capable of breaking the curse.

concepts.name: Bronze artifacts
concepts.context: Items purchased by the narrator from Wang Quansheng, potentially linked to the supernatural events.

concepts.name: Ghost
concepts.context: A supernatural entity that can result from improper handling of a reanimated corpse.

concepts.name: Nightmare
concepts.context: Recurring unsettling dreams experienced by the narrator, reflecting his anxieties.

concepts.name: Police
concepts.context: The authority figures investigating the mysterious deaths and disappearances.

concepts.name: Morgue
concepts.context: The place where Wang Quansheng's body was kept before disappearing.

concepts.name: Guesthouse
concepts.context: Shao Ye's establishment, serving as a base and a location for recent events.

concepts.name: Curse
concepts.context: A supernatural affliction linked to the Dragon Coffin and its users.

concepts.name: Dan Jun
concepts.context: A past victim whose death pose resembles that of the newly discovered corpse.

concepts.name: Hu Lai
concepts.context: The old man's subordinate, who reports on the unfolding supernatural events.

concepts.name: Uncle Luo
concepts.context: A person nearly injured by the reanimated Wang Quansheng.

concepts.name: God of Wealth (Cai Shen)
concepts.context: A euphemism used by the old man and Hu Lai for a reanimated corpse, specifically Wang Quansheng.

concepts.name: Soul (Hun Po)
concepts.context: The spiritual essence of a person, which can persist after death under certain conditions.

concepts.name: Jade bracelet
concepts.context: A valuable gift given by the old man to Yatou.

concepts.name: Embroidered pouch
concepts.context: Another gift from the old man to Yatou.

main_topics: Supernatural events surrounding Wang Quansheng's death
Investigation into a new murder and missing body
The curse of the Dragon Coffin
The mystery of Shadow Kunlun's Wind Eye
hierarchy.structure: The document follows a chronological narrative, detailing the narrator's experiences, nightmares, and subsequent involvement in an unfolding supernatural investigation. It moves from personal anxieties to a broader conspiracy involving ancient curses and potential treasures.
